body: I'll do another shallow pass. I can't test this as I currently don't have access to a Visual Studio 2013 box. Someone else will have to do the testing.

I've done another surface-level pass. Overall, I have a hard time with this change. It would help a lot to first describe the desired end goal on the JIRA ([REEF-289](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-289)) and then to work towards that in a set of smaller changes.

That isn't to say this change doesn't make things better. It does. But it is unclear how it relates to the overall plan for the Evaluator. If someone else can test this, I think it can be merged.
+1 on closing PRs we no longer believe should be considered for merging. @gwsshs22 can you please do that?
I've done a pass
I've done a pass. The logic behind the change looks good.

I have update JIRA REEF-1049 with the following:
As a sub tack of REEF-289, this PR is mainly for using Tang injection properly for the following classes:
Evaluator
HeartBeatManager
Contextmanager
EvaluatorRuntime
EvaluatorSettings

Evaluator reference to EvaluatorRuntime
EvaluatorRuntime has ContextManager and HeartBeatManager

EvaluatorConfigurations is consolidated into EvaluatorSettings which contains all the deserailzed configurations data from evaluator config file, and ContextConfiguration, Optional<TaskConfiguration> and Optional<ServiceConfiguration> and Evaluator injector. 

The evaluator config file is passed into Evaluator exe as a command line parameter, it is deserialized in main program so that to get injector, this injector is used to inject Evaluator, then all nested object including EvaluatorSetting are injected. 

The logic change is out of scope of this Jira. The reference relationship among EvaluatorRuntime, Contextmanager and HeartBeatManager are also not changed in this Jira.

I have addressed review comments
Updated JIRA for the issues resolved in the PR
reverted Logger rename as it is not part of the PR and make tehe real change not clear.

@afchung @tcNickolas how shall we proceed?

I need to experiment more to find which test causes this one to fail when executed in parallel. I don't think the fix should be placed in test, because if similar code is executed in parallel in non-test situation, the issue will still be there.
I'm not convinced that we should make the library or whichever data structure it's editing thread-safe. Can we set the tests to run in serial? Why are unit tests using a shared data structure?
`ProtoclBufferClassHierarchy` doesn't seem like it _needs_ to be a thread-safe class.

This may conflict with #738, but I believe the conflicts would not be difficult to handle: most of them will be removing `Serializable` from `TInput` and `TOutput`.

@afchung Could you please take a look?
Then, I have no objection for this, too. I'll test and merge this.

@afchung I've done a pass. I left some minor comments and a question. Could you check them? Thanks!

Thank you, @tcNickolas . I've changed according to your comments except `HashMap`. 

I chose `HashMap` because it's more primitive class. As you know, `HashSet` uses `HashMap`, so `HashSet` has more overhead than `HashMap` in terms of CPU/Memory. After updating the code according to your comments, I made and tested `HashSet` version multiple times again. The result shows `HashSet` version does not outperform the original `for-loop` version sometimes for some `n`.

Although there is a readability issue, I think this patch is meaningful only when it outperforms the original version.

And, I rebased and clean up the code for merging. For the previous patch diff, you can find in the following link.

https://app.box.com/s/4fir03lpw5y4jgh847c8tm0jan851nss

@afchung Thanks for the comments! I've fixed them.

Regarding the failure in serialization/deserialization, I think the main reason of failure is the misconfiguration, which we cannot handle in the runtime. I referred to [SerializationUtils](https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/apidocs/org/apache/commons/lang3/SerializationUtils.html#serialize%28java.io.Serializable%29), but of course there could be a better approach. Please let me know if you have any suggestion :)

Since we also need to update our Wiki page,   you can create another issue for that if you want. (The title of this PR is 'Fix typos'.)

@bgchun I've replied to a few of your comments, though I'm not sure if it answers your question or not. For tasklet failures, we assume that the tasklet throws an `Exception`. If a worker failed, we do not report tasklet failures but instead immediately reschedule it instead. Are there other scenarios I am missing? Thanks!

@bgchun @yunseong @johnyangk would like to know what you think of using a "ContinuationToken" approach for reporting tasklet aggregation, as mentioned above in reply to @yunseong 's comment. Are there any better alternatives?

@yunseong Thanks for the reply! My concern is the possibility for a single `SerializationException` crashing the entire `VortexMaster`, but perhaps we can develop a better story in a separate PR.

2. Create a new JIRA item for implementing `OnComplete`.
3. Create a new JIRA item for addressing concerns with caching connections.
4. Link all above JIRA items together.
5. Send out a new PR with updated titles and descriptions.

@afchung What code part is related to ContinuationToken?

@afchung The pattern looks good in general. 
Regarding 2, an Exception represents a Tasklet failure or multiple failures? Each Tasklet can fail with a different reason.

@bgchun I think there is some confusion with how to deal with failed Tasklets, so I'll enumerate how each failure plays out. Assume that a single worker has 3 Tasklets (A, B, and C) for this example, here would be how Tasklet failures are dealt with:
1. The A, B, and C fail individually -- the worker will create a single `WorkerReport`, with 3 `TaskletReports` of type `TaskletFailureReport`, each with the individual Exception that caused each its corresponding Tasklet to fail. The master, in this scenario, will invoke `VortexFutureDelegate.threwException` 3 times, each time only with a single item in the list and single Exception that caused the Tasklet to fail.
2. Tasklet A fails on its own, Tasklets B and C ran to succession but fail on aggregation -- the worker will create a single `WorkerReport`, with 2 `TaskletReports` of type `TaskletFailureReport`. The first `TaskletReport` will only contain Tasklet A in the list, and the Exception that caused Tasklet A to fail. The second `TaskletReport` will contain both Tasklet B and C in the list, and the Exception that caused the aggregation of Tasklet A and B to fail. The master, in this scenario, will invoke `VortexFutureDelegate.threwException` 2 times, the first time corresponding to Tasklet A's failure, the second time corresponding to Tasklet B and C's aggregation failure.
3. Tasklet A, B, and C all ran to succession, but fail on aggregation -- the worker will create a single `WorkerReport`, with a single `TaskletReport of type`TaskletFailureReport`. The`TaskletReport`will contain all 3 Tasklets in the list, and the single Exception that caused the aggregation of the 3 Tasklets to fail. The master, in this scenario, will invoke`VortexFutureDelegate.threwException` only 1 time, with Tasklets A, B, and C in the list, and the Exception corresponding to the Exception that caused the aggregation to fail.
4. The worker itself fails before reporting back to the master -- The master gets informed of the worker failure. Since it knows which Tasklets have not yet completed, it simply reschedules those Tasklets on another worker. `VortexFutureDelegate` does not get invoked until the Worker(s) that pick up the Tasklets report back.
5. The worker fails after reporting back to the master -- The master doesn't care, since the Tasklets have already completed. `VortexFutureDelegate` has already been invoked.

In short, a `TaskletReport` corresponds to a call to a method in `VortexFutureDelegate`. A `WorkerReport` contains a list of `TaskletReports`, potentially of the same type, but all reported from the same worker. If the result/failure is from an aggregation, the method in `VortexFutureDelegate` will get invoked with a list of Tasklets involved in the aggregation. If the result/failure is caused during the calculation of an individual Tasklet, the method in `VortexFutureDelegate` will only get invoked with a single Tasklet in the list, with a single result/Exception.

@bgchun Hopefully these examples clear things up. Please let me know if there are any other scenarios that might have been omitted. Thanks! I'll update the comments in the code if you think this makes sense.

@afchung Thanks for detailed explanation. I got it. It'd be really helpful to have detailed comments in `VortexFutureDelegate`. Having examples is good, too.

I think the confusion stems from the overloaded use of `threwException`. One option is to have two methods for explicit exception handling in the interface --- one for failure on aggregation and the other for tasklet failure.
Closing this PR to have a design discussion on JIRA.

@bgchun @afchung I resolved the merge conflicts. 
With changes in #738, `Tasklet` does not handle the result anymore; the result is passed by `VortexFutureDelegate` instead. So I added `OutputCodec` in `VortexFuture` where the result is the passed to user at the last moment. Could you please take a look and let me know if there would be a better solution? Thanks!
